BuildSystem.title: Project build system configuration
BuildSystem.description: Declares any Python level dependencies that must be installed in order to run the project’s build system successfully.
BuildSystem.markdownDescription: Declares any Python level dependencies that must be installed in order to run the project’s build system successfully.
BuildSystem.x-intellij-html-description: Declares any Python level dependencies that must be installed in order to run the project’s build system successfully.

requires.title: Build system dependencies
requires.description: List of strings following the version specifier specification, representing dependencies required to execute the build system.
requires.markdownDescription: List of strings following the [version specifier specification](https://packaging.python.org/en/latest/specifications/version-specifiers/#version-specifiers), representing dependencies required to execute the build system.
requires.x-intellij-html-description: List of strings following the version specifier specification, representing dependencies required to execute the build system.

build-backend.title: Name of Python object used to perform the build
build-backend.description: String is formatted following the same `module:object` syntax as a `setuptools` entry point. It’s also legal to leave out the `:object` part.

tool.title: Tool-specific configuration
tool.description: Every tool that is used by the project can have users specify configuration data as long as they use a sub-table within `[tool]`. Generally a project can use the subtable `tool.$NAME` if, and only if, they own the entry for `$NAME` in the Cheeseshop/PyPI.

maturin.title: Maturin
maturin.description: Build and publish crates with pyo3, cffi and uniffi bindings as well as rust binaries as python packages

tombi.title: TOML Toolkit
tombi.description: Tombi (鳶) is a toolkit for TOML; providing a formatter/linter and language server

project.title: Project core metadata
project.description:
There are two kinds of metadata: _static_ and _dynamic_.
- Static metadata is listed in the `[project]` table directly and cannot be specified or changed by a tool.
- Dynamic metadata key names are listed inside the `dynamic` key and represents metadata that a tool will later provide.
project.markdownDescription:
There are two kinds of metadata: _static_ and _dynamic_.
- Static metadata is listed in the `[project]` table directly and cannot be specified or changed by a tool.
- Dynamic metadata key names are listed inside the `dynamic` key and represents metadata that a tool will later provide.
project.x-intellij-html-description:
There are two kinds of metadata: static and dynamic.

  • Static metadata is listed in the [project] table directly and cannot be specified or changed by a tool.
  • Dynamic metadata key names are listed inside the dynamic key and represents metadata that a tool will later provide.

name.title: Project name
name.description: Valid name consists only of ASCII letters and numbers, period, underscore and hyphen. It must start and end with a letter or number.
name.markdownDescription: Valid name consists only of ASCII letters and numbers, period, underscore and hyphen. It must start and end with a letter or number.
name.x-intellij-html-description: Valid name consists only of ASCII letters and numbers, period, underscore and hyphen. It must start and end with a letter or number.

version.title: Project version
version.description: Version of the project, as defined in the [Version specifier specification](https://packaging.python.org/en/latest/specifications/version-specifiers/), and preferably [already normalized](https://packaging.python.org/en/latest/specifications/version-specifiers/#normalization).
version.markdownDescription: Version of the project, as defined in the [Version specifier specification](https://packaging.python.org/en/latest/specifications/version-specifiers/), and preferably [already normalized](https://packaging.python.org/en/latest/specifications/version-specifiers/#normalization).
version.x-intellij-html-description: Version of the project, as defined in the Version specifier specification, and preferably already normalized.

description.title: Project summary description
description.description: Summary description of the project in one line. Tools may not accept multiple lines.
description.markdownDescription: Summary description of the project in one line. Tools may not accept multiple lines.
description.x-intellij-html-description: Summary description of the project in one line. Tools may not accept multiple lines.

readme.title: Project full description
readme.description:
Value can be a relative path to text / markdown (`.md` suffix) / reStructuredText (`.rst` suffix) readme file, or a table with either:
- `file` key containing path of aforementioned readme file, or
- `text` key containing the full readme text embedded inside `pyproject.toml`.
readme.markdownDescription:
Value can be a relative path to text / markdown (`.md` suffix) / reStructuredText (`.rst` suffix) readme file, or a table with either:
- `file` key containing path of aforementioned readme file, or
- `text` key containing the full readme text embedded inside `pyproject.toml`.
readme.x-intellij-html-description:
Value can be a relative path to text / markdown (.md suffix) / reStructuredText (.rst suffix) readme file, or a table with either:

  • file key containing path of aforementioned readme file, or
  • text key containing the full readme text embedded inside pyproject.toml.

content-type.title: README text content-type
content-type.description: RFC 1341 compliant content-type (with optional charset, defaulting to UTF-8)

requires-python.title: Python version compatibility
requires-python.description: Specifies the Python version(s) that the distribution is compatible with. Must be in the format specified in [Version specifiers](https://packaging.python.org/en/latest/specifications/version-specifiers/).
requires-python.markdownDescription: Specifies the Python version(s) that the distribution is compatible with. Must be in the format specified in [Version specifiers](https://packaging.python.org/en/latest/specifications/version-specifiers/).
requires-python.x-intellij-html-description: Specifies the Python version(s) that the distribution is compatible with. Must be in the format specified in Version specifiers.

license.$comment: PEP 639 specifies current behavior (text / file subkey) will be deprecated, but this PEP is still under provisional status.
license.title: Project license
license.description:
For now it is a table with either:
- `file` key specifying a relative path to a license file, or
- `text` key containing full license content

Newer tool may accept a single [SPDX license expression](https://spdx.github.io/spdx-spec/v2.2.2/SPDX-license-expressions/) string instead of a table.

For now it is a table with either:

Newer tool may accept a single [SPDX license expression](https://spdx.github.io/spdx-spec/v2.2.2/SPDX-license-expressions/) string instead of a table.

scripts.title: Console scripts
scripts.description: Table of [entry points](https://packaging.python.org/en/latest/specifications/entry-points/) that allows package installers to create a command-line wrapper for. Each key is the name of the script to be created, and each value is the function or object to all, in form of either `importable.module` or `importable.module:object.attr`. Windows platform treats `console_scripts` specially in that they are wrapped in a console executable, so they are attached to a console and can use `sys.stdin`, `sys.stdout` and `sys.stderr` for I/O.
scripts.markdownDescription: Table of [entry points](https://packaging.python.org/en/latest/specifications/entry-points/) that allows package installers to create a command-line wrapper for. Each key is the name of the script to be created, and each value is the function or object to all, in form of either `importable.module` or `importable.module:object.attr`. Windows platform treats `console_scripts` specially in that they are wrapped in a console executable, so they are attached to a console and can use `sys.stdin`, `sys.stdout` and `sys.stderr` for I/O.

Windows platform treats console_scripts specially in that they are wrapped in a console executable, so they are attached to a console and can use sys.stdin, sys.stdout and sys.stderr for I/O.

gui-scripts.title: GUI scripts
gui-scripts.description: Table of [entry points](https://packaging.python.org/en/latest/specifications/entry-points/) that allows package installers to create a GUI wrapper for. Each key is the name of the script to be created, and each value is the function or object to all, in form of either `importable.module` or `importable.module:object.attr`. Windows platform treats `gui_scripts` specially in that they are wrapped in a GUI executable, so they can be started without a console, but cannot use standard streams unless application code redirects them.

entry-points.title: Other entry-point groups
entry-points.description: Extra [entry point groups](https://packaging.python.org/en/latest/specifications/entry-points/) that allow applications to load plugins. For example, Pygments (a syntax highlighting tool) can use additional styles from separately installed packages through `[project.entry-points."pygments.styles"]`. Each key is the name of the entry-point group, and each value is a table of entry points.

Each key is the name of the entry-point group, and each value is a table of entry points.

dependencies.title: Project mandatory dependency requirements
dependencies.description: An array of [dependency specifier](https://packaging.python.org/en/latest/specifications/dependency-specifiers/) strings, each representing a mandatory dependent package of the project.
dependencies.markdownDescription: An array of [dependency specifier](https://packaging.python.org/en/latest/specifications/dependency-specifiers/) strings, each representing a mandatory dependent package of the project.
dependencies.x-intellij-html-description: An array of dependency specifier strings, each representing a mandatory dependent package of the project.

optional-dependencies.title: Project extra dependency requirements
optional-dependencies.description: Each entry is a key/value pair, with the key specifying [extra feature name](https://packaging.python.org/en/latest/specifications/core-metadata/#provides-extra-multiple-use) (such as `socks` in `requests[socks]`), and value is an array of [dependency specifier](https://packaging.python.org/en/latest/specifications/dependency-specifiers/) strings.
optional-dependencies.markdownDescription: Each entry is a key/value pair, with the key specifying [extra feature name](https://packaging.python.org/en/latest/specifications/core-metadata/#provides-extra-multiple-use) (such as `socks` in `requests[socks]`), and value is an array of [dependency specifier](https://packaging.python.org/en/latest/specifications/dependency-specifiers/) strings.
optional-dependencies.x-intellij-html-description: Each entry is a key/value pair, with the key specifying extra feature name (such as socks in requests[socks]), and value is an array of dependency specifier strings.

dynamic.title: Dynamic metadata values
dynamic.description:
Specifies which keys are intentionally unspecified under `[project]` table so build backend can/will provide such metadata dynamically. Each key must be listed only once. It is an error to both list a key in `dynamic` and use the key directly in `[project]`.
One of the most common usage is `version`, which allows build backend to retrieve project version from source code or version control system instead of hardcoding it in `pyproject.toml`.
dynamic.markdownDescription:
Specifies which keys are intentionally unspecified under `[project]` table so build backend can/will provide such metadata dynamically. Each key must be listed only once. It is an error to both list a key in `dynamic` and use the key directly in `[project]`.
One of the most common usage is `version`, which allows build backend to retrieve project version from source code or version control system instead of hardcoding it in `pyproject.toml`.
dynamic.x-intellij-html-description:
Specifies which keys are intentionally unspecified under [project] table so build backend can/will provide such metadata dynamically. Each key must be listed only once. It is an error to both list a key in dynamic and use the key directly in [project].

One of the most common usage is version, which allows build backend to retrieve project version from source code or version control system instead of hardcoding it in pyproject.toml.

dependency-groups.title: PEP 735 dependency groups
dependency-groups.description: Named groups of dependencies, similar to `requirements.txt` files, which launchers, IDEs, and other tools can find and identify by name. Each item in `[dependency-groups]` is defined as mapping of group name to list of [dependency specifiers](https://packaging.python.org/en/latest/specifications/dependency-specifiers/).

Each item in `[dependency-groups]` is defined as mapping of group name to list of [dependency specifiers](https://packaging.python.org/en/latest/specifications/dependency-specifiers/).
